results.title: Marcel Proust: from masterpieces to a master's work
results.creator_credit: Jacques Letellier and C A P A C
results.brief_description: Intended to deepen our appreciation and understanding of Proust’s works by reviewing some of the masterpieces of art and music which inspired him and led him to recognise his vocation as a writer. The effect of the Dreyfus case and the Great War are indicated and the lack of interest in his work during his lifetime.
results.title_for_label: Marcel Proust: from masterpieces to a master’s work
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jacques Letellier and C A P A C

results.title: Marcel Duchamp: a game of chess
results.creator_credit: Jean-Marie Drot, RM Associates and INA France
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Filmed in 1963 the program offers an in-depth dialogue between renowned artist Marcel Duchamp and film-maker Jean-Marie Drot over a game of chess and a tour of Duchamp’s first one man show at the Pasadena Art Museum in 1963. Duchamp details his life and work only 5 years before his death in a discussion of his time in the United States after fleeing France in 1915. The discussion touches on his view of the country in social and political terms as well as its impact on his own work, intermingled with visual contemplations on the progression of his artwork from painting to photographs throughout his career. Recognised for varying artistic practices which included brushes with Impressionism and Cubism, Duchamp is also largely known for his founding influence in Surrealism and Dada. Here he recounts the stages of his work with full colour shots of the relevant pieces evoking a detailed sense of the significance of these different times in his life personally, politically and most of all artistically. The game of chess which punctuates the dialogue, a passion for Duchamp throughout his career, acts as an insightful metaphor for the mental discipline he applies to his work and an avenue for its explanation and contemplation. Contains some scenes in b&w. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Marcel
results.brief_description: Marcel stands aloft on a balcony as he watches 6 pallbearers carry an empty coffin; the pallbearers are coming for him. Cast includes John Bailey, Christopher Palmer, Johannes Davies, Davidson Wire, James Reg and William Frew.
results.description: Marcel stands aloft on a balcony as he watches 6 pallbearers carry an empty coffin; the pallbearers are coming for him. Cast includes John Bailey, Christopher Palmer, Johannes Davies, Davidson Wire, James Reg and William Frew.

results.title: Marceau on Mime
results.brief_description: Marcel Marceau, world famous French mime, talks about his life and work, about his theories on mime and the history of pantomime in the theatre. He traces mime through the Greek theatre, the commedia del’arte, the Pierrot of the 19th century and the comics of film, like Chaplin, Keaton, Lloyd, and Laurel and Hardy. Marceau started out to be a painter and still does drawings and paintings. He feels that mime is closely related to the graphic arts as well as to music and dance.

results.title: Marc Chagall/the colours of passion
results.creator_credit: Charles Harris and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: Focuses on the diverse artistic achievements of Marc Chagall. Explains his often perplexing subject matter and passion for colour in terms of his stated desire to create a world where anything is possible. Includes examples of his work, along with a discussion of his background and the influences of impressionism, cubism and Russia on his inspiration. Cameraman by Derek Waterman; quotations by Cyril Shaps and commentary by Paul Gregory. Suitable for Years 7-12.

results.title: Marc Chagall
results.creator_credit: Kim Evans, RM Arts and LWT
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
At a time when the world was turning toward Modernism. artist Marc Chagall had decided to finally leave his native Russia for Paris, the epi-centre of the art world at the turn of the 20th Century. Having suffered a poor and repressed childhood as a Russian Jew marginalised by poverty and cultural dissent Chagall’s iconography differed from his contemporaries. Whilst employing essentially a cubist surface his subject matter was deeply personal drawing on his life experiences. This documentary explores Chagall’s personal vision as artist and storyteller charting his career through his paintings, set and costume designs and stain glass work. Edited and presented by Melvyn Bragg.

results.title: Marbles
results.brief_description: Edward fears he is losing his grip on reality. Outwardly, he appears grumpier. Eventually he tells his wife she is the only thing that he can remember - but can she help him and what can be done? A poignant film about ageing, shot in black and white featuring Willie Fennell, Moya O’Sullivan and Noni Hazlehurst.

results.title: Marathon the ultimate challenge
results.creator_credit: Alan Jacques, Patrick Ramsey and Marathon Film Productions
results.brief_description: An award winning film about the determination, the satisfaction and the exhilaration of running a marathon. This film takes the viewer into a marathon and gives insight into what a runner experiences. This is more than a sports film - it is a film about setting a goal, working towards it and achieving it.

results.title: Marathon man (D)
results.creator_credit: John Schlesinger, Sidney Beckerman, Robert Evans and Connaught Productions
results.brief_description: Adapted by legendary screenwriter William Goldman from his own novel and directed by one of the seventies’ most intriguing filmmakers, John Schlesinger (Midnight Cowboy), ‘Marathon Man’ is one of that decade’s most handsome thrillers. Dustin Hoffman is Babe Levy, an impoverished history student living in the shadow of his father’s suicide. Daily, Babe tests himself running the streets of New York, but the ultimate test comes when his dubious brother (Roy Scheider) springboards the marathon man into an international conspiracy of diamonds, Nazis and double-crossings. Despite a stand-out performance by Laurence Olivier and some of the most well-known torture sequences in cinema history, ‘Marathon Man’ is perhaps little more than a run-of-the-mill thriller. Accepted as such, it is nonetheless a satisfying one.

results.title: Marathon I
results.creator_credit: Tim Kupsch and John Blackett-Smith Productions
results.brief_description: Looks at the individual training strategies and motivation of top world marathon runner Robert de Castella of Australia and Alberto Salazar of the USA. Follows each of them as they fight it out in the 1982 Rotterdam marathon, highlighting the incredible winning performance by de Castella, who after having run twenty-five miles at a rate of five minutes per mile, covered the last mile in a staggering four minutes and thirty-two seconds.
results.description: Looks at the individual training strategies and motivation of top world marathon runner Robert de Castella of Australia and Alberto Salazar of the USA. Follows each of them as they fight it out in the 1982 Rotterdam marathon, highlighting the incredible winning performance by de Castella, who after having run twenty-five miles at a rate of five minutes per mile, covered the last mile in a staggering four minutes and thirty-two seconds.
